G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the Probate and Family Court under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related statutes, as this action arises from a prior custody order issued by this Court.

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, courts may modify custody orders where there is a material and substantial change in circumstances that affects the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody determinations and repeatedly cites and applies the ‘best interests of the child’ standard, but it does so in the context of an initial or contemporaneous custody adjudication, not a modification of a prior custody order based on a material and substantial change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The court does not analyze or mention the statutory ‘material and substantial change’ requirement for modification proceedings, so it is not proper authority for that specific proposition, even though it is consistent with the general best‑interests framework.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … ‘must stand unless they are plainly wrong.’ … However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’” (463 Mass. at 494).

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The best interests of the child is the paramount concern in all custody modification proceedings. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion does state that the best interests of the child are the paramount concern in removal decisions under G.L. c. 208, § 30, and in custody determinations generally, but the case is not about a custody *modification* proceeding. It involves an initial divorce/custody judgment and a contemporaneous request to remove the children to Greece, not a later modification of an existing custody order. Thus, while Yannas is authority that best interests are paramount in custody and removal, it does not specifically stand for the proposition about all custody modification proceedings.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. … The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change…”}

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The best interests of the child is the paramount concern in all custody modification proceedings. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case clearly states that under G.L. c. 208, § 30, removal may be ordered only if it is in the child’s best interests, and it repeatedly frames the analysis in terms of the children’s best interests. However, the proceeding here is a removal dispute within an existing joint custody arrangement, not a generic “custody modification” proceeding, and the opinion does not broadly declare that best interests are the paramount concern in all custody modification cases. It does, though, reinforce that in this type of custody-related modification (removal), the best interests standard is controlling.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that … [a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not … be removed out of this Commonwealth… without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985) … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’”

*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237.proposition: The deterioration in Emily’s grades and academic performance as a direct consequence of Defendant’s actions indisputably impacts her welfare and educational development, thereby satisfying Massachusetts’ standard for modification of custody orders.
*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns Massachusetts’ standard for modification of existing custody orders based on deterioration in a child’s academic performance, but Custody of Zia is an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), not a modification case. The opinion does not discuss grade decline, school performance changes, or any requirement that such educational impact can by itself satisfy the standard for modifying custody. Instead, it focuses broadly on best interests, parenting judgment, and primary caretaker issues, so it does not provide authority for the specific modification standard asserted.
*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237.relevant_excerpt: “[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . . In addition to assessing the quality of the care provided by the primary caretaker, and the various factors specified in § 10(a) … a judge is to identify and weigh those factors pertinent to the child’s best interests.”

*Brazy v. Brazy*, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 903.proposition: In situations where one parent’s actions threaten the child’s well-being or future prospects, the Court has consistently held that custody orders should be modified to serve the child’s best interests. See *Brazy v. Brazy*, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 903 (2014); *Felix v. Felix*, 97 Mass. App. Ct. 714 (2020).
*Brazy v. Brazy*, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 903.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal appellate decision about sufficiency of the evidence and jury instructions for assault by means of a dangerous weapon; it does not involve custody, parental conduct, or modification of custody orders. Nothing in the reasoning addresses the best interests of a child or custody standards. Thus, citing Brazy v. Brazy for a rule about modifying custody orders when a parent threatens a child’s well-being is inaccurate and unsupported by this opinion.
*Brazy v. Brazy*, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 903.relevant_excerpt:
On appeal from a conviction of assault by means of a dangerous weapon, the defendant argues that (1) the evidence of assault under an attempted battery theory was insufficient, and (2) the judge’s instruction on that theory of assault gives rise to a substantial risk of a miscarriage of justice. We affirm.

1. Sufficiency of the evidence. Nancy Lizardo, the victim’s mother, related that during the encounter between the defendant and her son, Luis, she jumped between the two young men...

*Felix v. Felix*, 97 Mass. App. Ct. 714.proposition: In situations where one parent’s actions threaten the child’s well-being or future prospects, the Court has consistently held that custody orders should be modified to serve the child’s best interests. See *Brazy v. Brazy*, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 903 (2014); *Felix v. Felix*, 97 Mass. App. Ct. 714 (2020).
